message_1: A factory manufactures two products, Product A and Product B. Each unit of Product A requires 1 hour of assembly time and 2 hours of finishing time, while each unit of Product B requires 2 hours of assembly time and 1 hour of finishing time. The factory has 50 hours of available assembly time and 45 hours of available finishing time each day. Product A yields a profit of $10 per unit, and Product B yields a profit of $12 per unit. How many units of each product should the factory produce daily to maximize their profit?
message_2:
Let x be the number of units of Product A and y be the number of units of Product B.

The constraints for assembly time and finishing time are as follows:

1x + 2y ≤ 50 (assembly time constraint)
2x + 1y ≤ 45 (finishing time constraint)

The objective function to maximize the profit is:

P = 10x + 12y

First, we will find the feasible region by solving the constraints for x and y:

For the assembly time constraint:
x + 2y ≤ 50
x = 50 - 2y

For the finishing time constraint:
2x + y ≤ 45
y = 45 - 2x

Now, we will find the vertices of the feasible region by setting the equations equal to each other:

50 - 2y = 45 - 2x
2x - 2y = -5
x - y = -2.5

Solving for x:
x = y - 2.5

Substituting this into the equation for y:
y = 45 - 2(y - 2.5)
y = 45 - 2y + 5
3y = 50
y = 50/3 ≈ 16.67

Now, we will find the corresponding x value:
x = 16.67 - 2.5
x ≈ 14.17

Since we cannot produce a fraction of a product, we will consider the integer values around these numbers. We will check (14, 16), (14, 17), (15, 16), and (15, 17) to see which combination maximizes the profit.

For (14, 16):
P = 10(14) + 12(16) = 140 + 192 = $332

For (14, 17):
P = 10(14) + 12(17) = 140 + 204 = $344

For (15, 16):
P = 10(15) + 12(16) = 150 + 192 = $342

For (15, 17):
P = 10(15) + 12(17) = 150 + 204 = $354

The maximum profit of $354 is achieved when the factory produces 15 units of Product A and 17 units of Product B daily.
